dublin_core.dcvalue: In 1993 members of the National AIDS Commission were shocked by the number of physicians still refusing to care for AIDS patients Bill Pickney a physician in Arkansas says that the situation has changed today and health care providers are more sensitive about health care than they used to be However there seems to be a lack of training on how to provide adequate treatment to AIDS patients and current treatment regimens are very complex and change rapidly The Area Health Education Centers AHEC started in North Carolina in 1972 address training concerns of rural physicians and are now actively working to update skills for providing HIV treatments AHEC provides medical libraries computer assistance and continuing education programs in order to further develop a doctor s skills Telemedicine is being studied by AHEC as a possible solution to diagnostic and treatment concerns although the issue of telemedicine remains controversial
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-12T12:08:03Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 1999-03-11
Positively aware : the monthly journal of the Test Positive Aware Network
Health care strategies in rural America.
